issue.title: Add zero layer above all
issue.body:
Hi! Probably this isn't issue, but browsing through your code I coudn't find any solution. The point is that I'm trying to draw a "map" where contours (or layers) have both humps and holes (see figs attached). And in some holes the bottom layer is zero (pixels must not be filled). But when I subsequently overlay the contours and add the zero contour to the top, I see not an empty hole but the last underlying contour with minimal, but non-zero value. Could you please give some advice, how I could solve this problem?

Thanks in advance,
Dmitry

![frame_0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84021403/206161898-0aac7a3d-014a-421e-bc08-fde6f22af0e3.png)

comment.body:
Just a quick idea, the rasterizer gives awkward results for open paths. Are
you sure the paths are closed? You can close a polyline by appending the
starting point at the end.

On Fri, 9 Dec 2022, 07:59 dkononovGm, ***@***.***> wrote:

> Yes, here it is.
>
> This is the main loop overlaping layers ordered by the area (larger areas
> first, smaller atop)
>
> for _, rng := range contourPixelPoints {
> 		col := rng.Color
> 		ctx.SetFillColor(col)
> 		ctx.SetStrokeColor(col)
> 		ctx.SetStrokeWidth(0.0)
>
> 		line := pixelsToLine(rng.Line)
> 		//ctx.Style.FillRule = canvas.EvenOdd
> 		ctx.DrawPath(0, 0, line...)
> 	}
>

>

commits.message: Support path intersections with subpaths
Update docs
Add path boolean operator support (and,or,xor,not)
Polygon shapes either start at top or bottom depending on up boolean
Path join doesn't join if endpoints don't coincide
Add numerical stability for path intersections
Star and polygon shapes either start on the right (east) or top (north)
Fix angleBetween with Epsilon tolerance
Fix path boolean operation between empty paths
Revert starting point of polygon shapes wrt up
Add path boolean operations example to documentation

pull_request.title: Bump github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify](https://github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify) from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0.
Release notes

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's releases.

v1.6.0

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

  • kqueue: skip unreadable files (#479)

    kqueue requires a file descriptor for every file in a directory; this would fail if a file was unreadable by the current user. Now these files are simply skipped.

  • windows: fix renaming a watched directory if the parent is also watched (#370)

  • windows: increase buffer size from 4K to 64K (#485)

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's changelog.

[1.6.0] - 2022-10-13

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 5f8c606 Update ChangeLog
  • 8878587 Tweak the docs a bit
  • 89b4cf1 Add test for re-adding a renamed file (#508)
  • 85acde2 Update x/sys
  • 69c24b0 Update x/sys
  • fb07f82 Add test to see what happens if you watch a symlink (#498)
  • 666da9c Clarify doc comment on WatchList() (#499)
  • 123e4e3 Add note about README version
  • 61a05ce Update documentation and examples (#496)
  • e180a87 Move some inotify-tests to run on all backends; test that state is cleaned up...
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

issue.title: How to filter <script> tags in Html.Minify
issue.body:
Hi，
  There are some"<script type="text/html">" tags on my page, I don't want to minify it.
  How do I filter out <script> tags in the case of ”AddFunc("text/html", html.Minify)“ ？

comment.body: No, because you misspecified the MIME type of your template scripts, this may actually break in other cases as well. I recommend fixing the mime type to represent that correct template language you use, that way you can continue using minify.

issue.body:
Hey,

I am currently building a .net wrapper for minify. 
Therefore i would need the shared libraries for all the arches of linux, windows and MacOS.

All supported versions:

-- | --
Linux | Arm32 \| Arm32 Alpine \| Arm64 \| Arm64 Alpine \| x64 \| x64 Alpine
macOS | Arm64 \| x64
Windows | Arm64 \| x64 \| x86
All |

</body>
</html>

Source: https://dotnet.microsoft.com/en-us/download/dotnet/7.0

A 1:1 copy  of the js binding lib would be enougth

On windows i use ``go build --buildmode=c-shared -ldflags="-s -w"  -o main.dll .\minify.go `` to build a dll which works for me

GOOS=windows GOARCH=arm64 go build ${FLAGS} -o outfile ./cmd/minify
```

issue.title: Avoid minifying MIME types in type attribute
issue.body:
Hi, while using Hugo I stumbled upon this wrong behavior of the minifier, it minifies the string of the codec specified in the `source` element while it's not supposed to.

Example input

```
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
 <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4; codecs="av01.0.05M.08"">
</video>
```

Intended behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05M.08""></video>`

Actual behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05m.08""></video>`

(notice the M/m)

The [HTML Spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#mime-types) for MIME types is based on the [RFC 6381](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6381#section-3.3) that requires the codec string to be case sensitive.

It's possible to see how switching case in the codec strings breaks the codec support:
Open [media-mime-support test](http://cconcolato.github.io/media-mime-support/) and paste in the input box various codec strings like `av01.0.00H.12` and `av01.0.00h.12` etc., in the latter the test will return a negative result.

Reading in the past issues this seems a known problem already encountered by other users that was supposed to be fixed after #270 but it looks like this edge case was missed.

comment.body:
See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6838 for the reason why it was implemented this way though, it specifically states that parameter values should be case-insensitive. It seems to me that only string contents should be case sensitive, I've adjusted accordingly.

Anyways, is your HTML attribute valid with the nested double quotes?

issue.title: Avoid minifying MIME types in type attribute
issue.body:
Hi, while using Hugo I stumbled upon this wrong behavior of the minifier, it minifies the string of the codec specified in the `source` element while it's not supposed to.

Example input

```
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
 <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4; codecs="av01.0.05M.08"">
</video>
```

Intended behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05M.08""></video>`

Actual behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05m.08""></video>`

(notice the M/m)

The [HTML Spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#mime-types) for MIME types is based on the [RFC 6381](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6381#section-3.3) that requires the codec string to be case sensitive.

It's possible to see how switching case in the codec strings breaks the codec support:
Open [media-mime-support test](http://cconcolato.github.io/media-mime-support/) and paste in the input box various codec strings like `av01.0.00H.12` and `av01.0.00h.12` etc., in the latter the test will return a negative result.

Reading in the past issues this seems a known problem already encountered by other users that was supposed to be fixed after #270 but it looks like this edge case was missed.

issue.title: Add CIFuzz GitHub workflow
issue.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where Minify already runs (Ref https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/tree/master/projects/minify and https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/3848). CIFuzz can help detect regressions, bring fuzzing closer into the development workflow, and catch fuzzing build issues early. CIFuzz has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

issue.body:
I'm sorry, I must be missing a setting somewhere but I've looked at the docs and issues ...
The output SVG is upside down?

```
        fontFamily := canvas.NewFontFamily("Geneva")
	if err := fontFamily.LoadFontFile("/System/Library/Fonts/Geneva.ttf", canvas.FontBold); err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	face := fontFamily.Face(80.0, canvas.Black, canvas.FontBold, canvas.FontNormal)
	path, _, err := face.ToPath(text)
	if err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	tpl := `<svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" height="400" width="800">
		<path d="%s" />
	</svg>`
	fmt.Printf(tpl, path.ToSVG())
```

comment.body:
Canvas works in the first Cartesian quadrant (the default for mathematics)
while SVG uses the fourth. You need to flip the canvas vertically, setting
the context View for example.

issue.title: Rasterization performance
issue.body:
Improve rasterization performance. How does FreeType perform? Why is the `vector` one slow?

- `vector`: https://github.com/golang/image/tree/master/vector
- FreeType: https://github.com/golang/freetype
- `exp`: https://github.com/golang/exp/blob/master/shiny/iconvg/rasterizer.go
- `rasterx`: https://github.com/srwiley/rasterx for a combination of `vector` and FreeType

Make sure the new rasterizer supports both fill types: `EvenOdd` and `NonZero`  (`vector` does not support `EvenOdd`).

EDIT: see the following links for some ideas.

- `font-rs`: https://medium.com/@raphlinus/inside-the-fastest-font-renderer-in-the-world-75ae5270c445, also see https://www.cryptologie.net/article/406/simd-instructions-in-go for implementing in Go
- Signed distance fields: https://github.com/Chlumsky/msdfgen

EDIT: actually, Nigel Tao has an implementation of `font-rs` in Go here: https://github.com/google/font-go. It says in https://github.com/golang/image/blob/master/vector/vector.go that `font-go` is proof of concept, but doesn't actually import `vector`...?

issue.title: Cubic root not found
issue.body: Solving for the cubic polynomial `16t^3 - 24t^2 + 24t - 8 = 0` should give `0.5` as a real root, but looking at https://github.com/davideberly/GeometricTools/blob/6238789eaf9653e9eec4432ce06821552760c65e/GTL/Mathematics/RootFinders/RootsQuadratic.h#L98 it seems that this case is not covered. For this particular polynomial, the depressed cubic polynomial is `x^3 + 0.75x + 0 = 0` (i.e. `c1 = 0.75` and `c0 = 0`), which gets passed to the code for a depressed quadratic where `c0` is the `c1` from before. Clearly, `c0 = 0.75 > 0` which goes to the line above, but that is false!

issue.body:
For many embedded devices, were the use of minify its very important due to low memory availability, the case of some objects or labels its very important too, for example in tpl files used in web pages on some of the devices we use a lot of labels like #SomeLabelId# or tags like @TagId@ and the code inside, usually C or C++, its expecting the label/tag in the same case, I see no cmd ñline option for preserve case.

Could you add a option for this requirement?
Thanks

comment.body: Thanks for clarifying! Unfortunately there is no TPL minifier (yet), and passing a TPL file to the HTML minifier is a very bad idea. Even though TPL looks like HTML (and is converted to it), it is still not trivial for all edge cases to be covered. There have been many requests though, and I'd like to create a TPL minifier that can accept any type of begin/end tags (such as `%`, `<?php`, `?>`, ...)

issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }
>

pull_request.title: Bump github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify](https://github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify) from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0.
Release notes

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's releases.

v1.6.0

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

  • kqueue: skip unreadable files (#479)

    kqueue requires a file descriptor for every file in a directory; this would fail if a file was unreadable by the current user. Now these files are simply skipped.

  • windows: fix renaming a watched directory if the parent is also watched (#370)

  • windows: increase buffer size from 4K to 64K (#485)

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's changelog.

[1.6.0] - 2022-10-13

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

... (truncated)

comment.body: No, because you misspecified the MIME type of your template scripts, this may actually break in other cases as well. I recommend fixing the mime type to represent that correct template language you use, that way you can continue using minify.

issue.title: Avoid minifying MIME types in type attribute
issue.body:
Hi, while using Hugo I stumbled upon this wrong behavior of the minifier, it minifies the string of the codec specified in the `source` element while it's not supposed to.

Example input

```
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
 <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4; codecs="av01.0.05M.08"">
</video>
```

Intended behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05M.08""></video>`

Actual behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05m.08""></video>`

(notice the M/m)

The [HTML Spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#mime-types) for MIME types is based on the [RFC 6381](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6381#section-3.3) that requires the codec string to be case sensitive.

It's possible to see how switching case in the codec strings breaks the codec support:
Open [media-mime-support test](http://cconcolato.github.io/media-mime-support/) and paste in the input box various codec strings like `av01.0.00H.12` and `av01.0.00h.12` etc., in the latter the test will return a negative result.

Reading in the past issues this seems a known problem already encountered by other users that was supposed to be fixed after #270 but it looks like this edge case was missed.

comment.body:
See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6838 for the reason why it was implemented this way though, it specifically states that parameter values should be case-insensitive. It seems to me that only string contents should be case sensitive, I've adjusted accordingly.

Anyways, is your HTML attribute valid with the nested double quotes?

issue.title: Add CIFuzz GitHub workflow
issue.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where Minify already runs (Ref https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/tree/master/projects/minify and https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/3848). CIFuzz can help detect regressions, bring fuzzing closer into the development workflow, and catch fuzzing build issues early. CIFuzz has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

comment.body: Thanks!

Add CIFuzz GitHub workflow

issue.title: SVG text is upside down / flipped on y axis
issue.body:
I'm sorry, I must be missing a setting somewhere but I've looked at the docs and issues ...
The output SVG is upside down?

```
        fontFamily := canvas.NewFontFamily("Geneva")
	if err := fontFamily.LoadFontFile("/System/Library/Fonts/Geneva.ttf", canvas.FontBold); err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	face := fontFamily.Face(80.0, canvas.Black, canvas.FontBold, canvas.FontNormal)
	path, _, err := face.ToPath(text)
	if err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	tpl := `<svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" height="400" width="800">
		<path d="%s" />
	</svg>`
	fmt.Printf(tpl, path.ToSVG())
```

comment.body:
Canvas works in the first Cartesian quadrant (the default for mathematics)
while SVG uses the fourth. You need to flip the canvas vertically, setting
the context View for example.

On Sun, 27 Nov 2022, 15:44 David Smith, ***@***.***> wrote:

issue.title: Supported by tdewolff/canvas
issue.body:
Hey Sebastian, I've added support for this library by default with https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/commit/5040a658ae12da048839230d182758287e311658. Users can opt-in to use the LaTeX binaries instead, by using the build tag `latex`. Really great work so far! Highly apreciated ;-)

I have a few questions regarding the library:
- What does `tex.Ship` do in https://github.com/go-latex/latex/blob/main/mtex/render.go#L37?

issue.title: Rasterization performance
issue.body:
Improve rasterization performance. How does FreeType perform? Why is the `vector` one slow?

- `vector`: https://github.com/golang/image/tree/master/vector
- FreeType: https://github.com/golang/freetype
- `exp`: https://github.com/golang/exp/blob/master/shiny/iconvg/rasterizer.go
- `rasterx`: https://github.com/srwiley/rasterx for a combination of `vector` and FreeType

Make sure the new rasterizer supports both fill types: `EvenOdd` and `NonZero`  (`vector` does not support `EvenOdd`).

EDIT: see the following links for some ideas.

- `font-rs`: https://medium.com/@raphlinus/inside-the-fastest-font-renderer-in-the-world-75ae5270c445, also see https://www.cryptologie.net/article/406/simd-instructions-in-go for implementing in Go
- Signed distance fields: https://github.com/Chlumsky/msdfgen

EDIT: actually, Nigel Tao has an implementation of `font-rs` in Go here: https://github.com/google/font-go. It says in https://github.com/golang/image/blob/master/vector/vector.go that `font-go` is proof of concept, but doesn't actually import `vector`...?

issue.title: Cubic root not found
issue.body: Solving for the cubic polynomial `16t^3 - 24t^2 + 24t - 8 = 0` should give `0.5` as a real root, but looking at https://github.com/davideberly/GeometricTools/blob/6238789eaf9653e9eec4432ce06821552760c65e/GTL/Mathematics/RootFinders/RootsQuadratic.h#L98 it seems that this case is not covered. For this particular polynomial, the depressed cubic polynomial is `x^3 + 0.75x + 0 = 0` (i.e. `c1 = 0.75` and `c0 = 0`), which gets passed to the code for a depressed quadratic where `c0` is the `c1` from before. Clearly, `c0 = 0.75 > 0` which goes to the line above, but that is false!

In any case, thank you for this excellent repository and the accompanying papers.

issue.title: Case its important sometimes
issue.body:
For many embedded devices, were the use of minify its very important due to low memory availability, the case of some objects or labels its very important too, for example in tpl files used in web pages on some of the devices we use a lot of labels like #SomeLabelId# or tags like @TagId@ and the code inside, usually C or C++, its expecting the label/tag in the same case, I see no cmd ñline option for preserve case.

Could you add a option for this requirement?
Thanks

comment.body: Thanks for clarifying! Unfortunately there is no TPL minifier (yet), and passing a TPL file to the HTML minifier is a very bad idea. Even though TPL looks like HTML (and is converted to it), it is still not trivial for all edge cases to be covered. There have been many requests though, and I'd like to create a TPL minifier that can accept any type of begin/end tags (such as `%`, `<?php`, `?>`, ...)

issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

```
background-position:center left  =>  background-position:0 50%

issue.title: panic in RichText.ToText on initial and consecutive newlines
issue.body:
Calling `Context.DrawText` with a `TextBox` containing a newline at the start of the text string, or multiple newlines in a row, results in a panic due to an index out of range error.

The offending line is [here](https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/blob/6bed7f464e8fc4ae2a3249ac010ec98d6f0ba716/text.go#L447) - apparently `t.lines[j].spans` ends up being `nil` here.

MWE:
```go
func TestTextBox(t *testing.T) {
	c := canvas.New(100, 100)
	ctx := canvas.NewContext(c)
	font, err := canvas.LoadFontFile("/usr/share/fonts/liberation/LiberationSans-Bold.ttf", canvas.FontRegular)
	if err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
	face := font.Face(12, canvas.Black)
	//ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "\ntext", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: What is the advantages of html lexer of this package?
issue.body:
I am curious that what is advantages / use cases of html lexer of this package over tokenizer from https://pkg.go.dev/golang.org/x/net/html.

Could you explain for me?

Thanks.

comment.body: To be honest I haven't used that library, but I don't think there are a lot of differences w.r.t. functionality. That being said, it is likely that this library is faster (which I vaguely remember being the principal reason for writing my own parser). Otherwise, some small API differences.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }
>

issue.body:
Hi! Probably this isn't issue, but browsing through your code I coudn't find any solution. The point is that I'm trying to draw a "map" where contours (or layers) have both humps and holes (see figs attached). And in some holes the bottom layer is zero (pixels must not be filled). But when I subsequently overlay the contours and add the zero contour to the top, I see not an empty hole but the last underlying contour with minimal, but non-zero value. Could you please give some advice, how I could solve this problem?

Thanks in advance,
Dmitry

pull_request.title: Bump github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify](https://github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify) from 1.5.4 to 1.6.0.
Release notes

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's releases.

v1.6.0

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

  • kqueue: skip unreadable files (#479)

    kqueue requires a file descriptor for every file in a directory; this would fail if a file was unreadable by the current user. Now these files are simply skipped.

  • windows: fix renaming a watched directory if the parent is also watched (#370)

  • windows: increase buffer size from 4K to 64K (#485)

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from github.com/fsnotify/fsnotify's changelog.

[1.6.0] - 2022-10-13

This version of fsnotify needs Go 1.16 (this was already the case since 1.5.1, but not documented). It also increases the minimum Linux version to 2.6.32.

Additions

  • all: add Event.Has() and Op.Has() (#477)

    This makes checking events a lot easier; for example:

    if event.Op&Write == Write && !(event.Op&Remove == Remove) {
}

    Becomes:

    if event.Has(Write) && !event.Has(Remove) {
}

  • all: add cmd/fsnotify (#463)

    A command-line utility for testing and some examples.

Changes and fixes

  • inotify: don't ignore events for files that don't exist (#260, #470)

    Previously the inotify watcher would call os.Lstat() to check if a file still exists before emitting events.

    This was inconsistent with other platforms and resulted in inconsistent event reporting (e.g. when a file is quickly removed and re-created), and generally a source of confusion. It was added in 2013 to fix a memory leak that no longer exists.

  • all: return ErrNonExistentWatch when Remove() is called on a path that's not watched (#460)

  • inotify: replace epoll() with non-blocking inotify (#434)

    Non-blocking inotify was not generally available at the time this library was written in 2014, but now it is. As a result, the minimum Linux version is bumped from 2.6.27 to 2.6.32. This hugely simplifies the code and is faster.

  • kqueue: don't check for events every 100ms (#480)

    The watcher would wake up every 100ms, even when there was nothing to do. Now it waits until there is something to do.

  • macos: retry opening files on EINTR (#475)

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 5f8c606 Update ChangeLog
  • 8878587 Tweak the docs a bit
  • 89b4cf1 Add test for re-adding a renamed file (#508)
  • 85acde2 Update x/sys
  • 69c24b0 Update x/sys
  • fb07f82 Add test to see what happens if you watch a symlink (#498)
  • 666da9c Clarify doc comment on WatchList() (#499)
  • 123e4e3 Add note about README version
  • 61a05ce Update documentation and examples (#496)
  • e180a87 Move some inotify-tests to run on all backends; test that state is cleaned up...
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

issue.title: Avoid minifying MIME types in type attribute
issue.body:
Hi, while using Hugo I stumbled upon this wrong behavior of the minifier, it minifies the string of the codec specified in the `source` element while it's not supposed to.

Example input

```
<video width="320" height="240" controls>
 <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4; codecs="av01.0.05M.08"">
</video>
```

Intended behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05M.08""></video>`

Actual behavior:
`<video width=320 height=240 controls><source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4;codecs="av01.0.05m.08""></video>`

(notice the M/m)

The [HTML Spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#mime-types) for MIME types is based on the [RFC 6381](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6381#section-3.3) that requires the codec string to be case sensitive.

It's possible to see how switching case in the codec strings breaks the codec support:
Open [media-mime-support test](http://cconcolato.github.io/media-mime-support/) and paste in the input box various codec strings like `av01.0.00H.12` and `av01.0.00h.12` etc., in the latter the test will return a negative result.

Reading in the past issues this seems a known problem already encountered by other users that was supposed to be fixed after #270 but it looks like this edge case was missed.

comment.body:
See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6838 for the reason why it was implemented this way though, it specifically states that parameter values should be case-insensitive. It seems to me that only string contents should be case sensitive, I've adjusted accordingly.

Anyways, is your HTML attribute valid with the nested double quotes?

issue.title: Add CIFuzz GitHub workflow
issue.body:
Add [CIFuzz](https://google.github.io/oss-fuzz/getting-started/continuous-integration/) workflow action to have fuzzers build and run on each PR.

This is a service offered by OSS-Fuzz where Minify already runs (Ref https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/tree/master/projects/minify and https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/3848). CIFuzz can help detect regressions, bring fuzzing closer into the development workflow, and catch fuzzing build issues early. CIFuzz has a variety of features (see the URL above). In the current PR the fuzzers gets build on a pull request and will run for 300 seconds.

issue.body:
I'm sorry, I must be missing a setting somewhere but I've looked at the docs and issues ...
The output SVG is upside down?

```
        fontFamily := canvas.NewFontFamily("Geneva")
	if err := fontFamily.LoadFontFile("/System/Library/Fonts/Geneva.ttf", canvas.FontBold); err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	face := fontFamily.Face(80.0, canvas.Black, canvas.FontBold, canvas.FontNormal)
	path, _, err := face.ToPath(text)
	if err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	tpl := `<svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" height="400" width="800">
		<path d="%s" />
	</svg>`
	fmt.Printf(tpl, path.ToSVG())
```

comment.body:
Canvas works in the first Cartesian quadrant (the default for mathematics)
while SVG uses the fourth. You need to flip the canvas vertically, setting
the context View for example.

Hey Sebastian, I've added support for this library by default with https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/commit/5040a658ae12da048839230d182758287e311658. Users can opt-in to use the LaTeX binaries instead, by using the build tag `latex`. Really great work so far! Highly apreciated ;-)

I have a few questions regarding the library:
- What does `tex.Ship` do in https://github.com/go-latex/latex/blob/main/mtex/render.go#L37?
- What does `Depth()` mean in https://github.com/go-latex/latex/blob/main/mtex/render.go#L42?
- What does `Glyph.Offset` mean in https://github.com/go-latex/latex/blob/main/drawtex/canvas.go#L56?
- What is the difference between `Default`  and `Rm` fonts, and do I need to specify math versions of a font?
- Some functionality was missing I found, such as `left(` and `\right)`

Thanks for the work so far! I've also tried to use the STIX fonts you provide, but the glyph size or advance was bad in my case (maybe a problem at my end?). What is the status on supporting the Latin Modern fonts?

issue.title: Rasterization performance
issue.body:
Improve rasterization performance. How does FreeType perform? Why is the `vector` one slow?

- `vector`: https://github.com/golang/image/tree/master/vector
- FreeType: https://github.com/golang/freetype
- `exp`: https://github.com/golang/exp/blob/master/shiny/iconvg/rasterizer.go
- `rasterx`: https://github.com/srwiley/rasterx for a combination of `vector` and FreeType

Make sure the new rasterizer supports both fill types: `EvenOdd` and `NonZero`  (`vector` does not support `EvenOdd`).

EDIT: see the following links for some ideas.

- `font-rs`: https://medium.com/@raphlinus/inside-the-fastest-font-renderer-in-the-world-75ae5270c445, also see https://www.cryptologie.net/article/406/simd-instructions-in-go for implementing in Go
- Signed distance fields: https://github.com/Chlumsky/msdfgen

EDIT: actually, Nigel Tao has an implementation of `font-rs` in Go here: https://github.com/google/font-go. It says in https://github.com/golang/image/blob/master/vector/vector.go that `font-go` is proof of concept, but doesn't actually import `vector`...?

issue.title: Cubic root not found
issue.body: Solving for the cubic polynomial `16t^3 - 24t^2 + 24t - 8 = 0` should give `0.5` as a real root, but looking at https://github.com/davideberly/GeometricTools/blob/6238789eaf9653e9eec4432ce06821552760c65e/GTL/Mathematics/RootFinders/RootsQuadratic.h#L98 it seems that this case is not covered. For this particular polynomial, the depressed cubic polynomial is `x^3 + 0.75x + 0 = 0` (i.e. `c1 = 0.75` and `c0 = 0`), which gets passed to the code for a depressed quadratic where `c0` is the `c1` from before. Clearly, `c0 = 0.75 > 0` which goes to the line above, but that is false!

For this particular polynomial, the depressed cubic polynomial is `x^3 + 0.75x + 0 = 0` (i.e. `c1 = 0.75` and `c0 = 0`), which gets passed to the code for a depressed quadratic where `c0` is the `c1` from before. In any case, thank you for this excellent repository and the accompanying papers.

issue.title: Case its important sometimes
issue.body:
For many embedded devices, were the use of minify its very important due to low memory availability, the case of some objects or labels its very important too, for example in tpl files used in web pages on some of the devices we use a lot of labels like #SomeLabelId# or tags like @TagId@ and the code inside, usually C or C++, its expecting the label/tag in the same case, I see no cmd ñline option for preserve case.

Could you add a option for this requirement?
Thanks

comment.body: Thanks for clarifying! Unfortunately there is no TPL minifier (yet), and passing a TPL file to the HTML minifier is a very bad idea. Even though TPL looks like HTML (and is converted to it), it is still not trivial for all edge cases to be covered. There have been many requests though, and I'd like to create a TPL minifier that can accept any type of begin/end tags (such as `%`, `<?php`, `?>`, ...)

issue.title: Cubic root not found
issue.body: Solving for the cubic polynomial `16t^3 - 24t^2 + 24t - 8 = 0` should give `0.5` as a real root, but looking at https://github.com/davideberly/GeometricTools/blob/6238789eaf9653e9eec4432ce06821552760c65e/GTL/Mathematics/RootFinders/RootsQuadratic.h#L98 it seems that this case is not covered. For this particular polynomial, the depressed cubic polynomial is `x^3 + 0.75x + 0 = 0` (i.e. `c1 = 0.75` and `c0 = 0`), which gets passed to the code for a depressed quadratic where `c0` is the `c1` from before. Clearly, `c0 = 0.75 > 0` which goes to the line above, but that is false!

issue.title: Removing unused catch params breaks JS on older Apple devices
issue.body:
Hi, thanks for all your hard work!

I noticed you recently removed try/catch params if there are no parameter bindings: https://github.com/tdewolff/minify/commit/2e77ff31bcd4eab25e4afc058c4a521384be68b0

This produces statements like this:
```javascript
try {
   1/0
} catch {
   console.log('Oops!')
}
```

This code is valid in most browsers, but not in older Apple devices (Safari on desktop or iPhones / iPads).  So far this is the only incompatibility I've noticed when minifying JS for these platforms, and my only workaround is to explicitly reference the parameter so the minifier doesn't drop the param.

Here's what it looks like in a Safari console:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/266265/199272097-2f117487-0f4d-40ed-b3d0-08935ce34c69.png)

I'm not sure what level of compatibility you're aiming for, but if we could put this behind a flag or handle it differently, that would be great!

I am a Go developer, so if you'd like a PR, just let me know what path you'd like to go down.

comment.body: Thanks for the issue, this should now be fixed by passing the `Version = 2018` option to the JS minifier.

issue.title: Fix background-position minification
issue.body: Fixes #221: order of converted numbers for `background-position: top right`, `bottom left`, `top center`, `bottom center`; disables incorrect conversion for `background-position: top` and `background-position: bottom`.

comment.body:
Thanks, I see what the problem is. This is a minimal reproducible example:
```
background-position:center left  =>  background-position:0 50%
```

That is because the first value should be the X axis and the second the Y. That means that `center left` is valid, but when no keywords are used the order should be reversed.

issue.title: panic in RichText.ToText on initial and consecutive newlines
issue.body:
Calling `Context.DrawText` with a `TextBox` containing a newline at the start of the text string, or multiple newlines in a row, results in a panic due to an index out of range error.

The offending line is [here](https://github.com/tdewolff/canvas/blob/6bed7f464e8fc4ae2a3249ac010ec98d6f0ba716/text.go#L447) - apparently `t.lines[j].spans` ends up being `nil` here.

MWE:
```go
func TestTextBox(t *testing.T) {
	c := canvas.New(100, 100)
	ctx := canvas.NewContext(c)
	font, err := canvas.LoadFontFile("/usr/share/fonts/liberation/LiberationSans-Bold.ttf", canvas.FontRegular)
	if err != nil {
		t.Fatal(err)
	}
	face := font.Face(12, canvas.Black)
	//ctx.DrawText(0, 0, canvas.NewTextBox(face, "\ntext", 100, 100, canvas.Left, canvas.Top, 0, 0))

pull_request.title: JS: add ast JSWriteTo method
pull_request.body:
I often edit ast, modify some data, and then convert ast back to js code, ast.JS() is too slow and takes up a lot of memory

Using buffers can greatly improve efficiency

```
BenchmarkJsAstJSWriteTo-2        10           194873291 ns/op      36253063 B/op    1031732 allocs/op
BenchmarkJsAstJS-2               10          1559868949 ns/op    2160659760 B/op    1057158 allocs/op
```

```go
// JSWriteTo
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
var buf bytes.Buffer
ast.JSWriteTo(&buf)

// JS
ast, _ := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
...
ast.JS()
```

If this is useful, consider this pr

pull_request.title: fix stroke width scaling being NaN with CartesianIV
pull_request.body:
When using `CartesianIV` as your coordinate system, you end up with a translation matrix that looks like
```
[[1 0]
 [0 -1]]
```
which has a negative determinant. This PR takes the absolute value of the determinant before calculating the square root to avoid the scaling of the stroke width becoming `NaN`.

issue.title: Writing to a file doesn't wait for the file to be written to before returning
issue.body:
If you have any canvas, then try writing the data to a PNG (I'm guessing this will also happen with other data types) with this code:

```GO
renderers.Write("<PATH>", c)
```

The function will return before the file has been written to. This is a problem for me since I am connecting this with a webserver, so am receiving both `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and `ERR_CONTENT_LENGTH_MISMATCH` errors some of the time. The way I can fix this currently is to add a very small delay between the function returning and the webserver responding with an image, but this isn't ideal.

Would it be possible to either make the function return once the file is written, or add some kind of option to allow it?

comment.body: Thanks for the follow-up, indeed `canvas` closes the file before returning, so it must be a problem at the webserver side.

issue.title: Fast js detection

comment.body:
Hi tmr,

Thank you for writing to me. As you can read in the issue, this is not a
problem of the lexer or parser, but rather a property of the JS language.
You cannot lex a JS source code without also parsing it. You can use a rule
that is 99% of the time correct (see the original JS parser, or the one
from Douglas Crockford (http://www.crockford.com/jsmin.html) , but if you
want to be 100% of the time correct you need to properly parse JS. What I
don't understand is when you refer to slow or fast, what has speed to do
with the issue?

Saludos cordiales,
Taco de Wolff


On Tue, Oct 11, 2022 at 4:49 AM tmr ***@***.***> wrote:

> I use js.Parser to detect if some string is js code, but it's slow again
> for me
>
> I tried using js.Lexer, but that doesn't seem to work, I'm getting regex
> parsing errors, see some related issues, like #72
> <https://github.com/tdewolff/parse/issues/72>, regex seems very difficult
> to handle in Lexer
>
> I would like to ask is there any way to simplify js.Parser to detect js
> and make it faster
>
> // works, but too slowfunc JsDetect(body []byte) bool {
> 	_, err := js.Parse(parse.NewInputBytes(body), js.Options{})
> 	return err == nil
> }
>
> // hope it works, but nofunc JsDetect2(body []byte) bool {
> 	l := js.NewLexer(parse.NewInputBytes(body))
> 	for {
> 		tt, _ := l.Next()
> 		switch tt {
> 		case js.ErrorToken:
> 			if l.Err() != io.EOF {
> 				return false
> 			} else {
> 				return true
> 			}
> 		}
> 	}
> }
